abstract: The big discount chain has sought to reduce the property taxes it pays on 35 percent of its stores, according to a report by Good Jobs First, a group critical of Wal-Mart.
snippet: The big discount chain has sought to reduce the property taxes it pays on 35 percent of its stores, according to a report by Good Jobs First, a group critical of Wal-Mart.
lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart doesn’t believe just in lower prices — it believes in lower property taxes, too. The big discount chain has sought to reduce the property taxes it pays on 35 percent of its stores and 40 percent of its distribution centers, according to a report to be released today by Good Jobs First, a group that is critical of Wal-Mart.

headline.main: Study Says Wal-Mart Often Fights Local Taxes
headline.print_headline: Study Says Wal-Mart Often Fights Local Taxes
